result.execSummary:
The defendant Beau William Diver was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Felony, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt:
8:20 AM Defendant Beau William Diver in court.  Attorney Chris A Gramstrup appeared by video for Beau William Diver.  Attorney Kenneth N. Sortedahl in court for State of Wisconsin. Court calls case and recites appearances. Plea Questionnaire electronically submitted to Court.  State recites the agreement, all parties agree.    DEF agrees to proceed with attorney appearing by video.   Court reviews information, DEF enters guilty plea to Count 1.   DEF advised of rights and penalties; DEF waives rights; parties stipulate to facts.   Court accepts plea to Count 1 and finds DEF guilty.    Counts 2  are dismissed and read in.  

COURT:   withheld sentence  3 year probation.  Condition of probation:  AODA assessment  within 45 days and follow-through with recommendations.   Complete any counseling and programming deemed appropriate by agent, and follow through.   No Contact with Wal-Mart of Hayward and L & M of Hayward.   Fine/Costs  $654.00  DEF must provide DNA sample and pay applicable $250 surcharge.     Probation is concurrent.
